Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Chronic hypertension leads to degenerative changes in the walls of small intracerebral arteries—hyaline arteriolosclerosis and lipohyalinosis—resulting in Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysm formation and rupture. These lesions most often cause deep intracerebral hemorrhages in the basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, or cerebellum. By contrast, coagulopathies (e.g., warfarin, thrombocytopenia) produce diffuse or lobar bleeds; ruptured saccular aneurysms present with subarachnoid hemorrhage; and arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) manifest as high‐flow vascular tangles prone to lobar hemorrhage or seizures. Key terminology: lipohyalinosis, Charcot–Bouchard aneurysm, lenticulostriate arteries.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hypertension is the leading cause of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), accounting for approximately 70–80% of cases (van Asch et al., Lancet Neurol 2010). Chronic elevated blood pressure induces fibrinoid necrosis and smooth muscle degeneration in small perforating arterioles; pathologic examination reveals hyaline deposits and microaneurysm formation (Fisher, Stroke 2003). When these weakened vessels rupture, they release blood into deep brain structures, producing a hyperdense region on noncontrast CT. The 2022 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines emphasize early recognition of hypertensive ICH and acute blood pressure management to reduce hematoma expansion (Class I, Level B-R).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Coagulopathy
• Incorrect because primary hemostatic defects cause multifocal or lobar hemorrhages and often present with prolonged bleeding times and multiple small hematomas rather than a single deep bleed.
• Misconception: Equating any intracerebral hemorrhage with coagulopathy overlooks the characteristic deep basal ganglia location of hypertensive bleeds.

C. Aneurysm
• Saccular (“berry”) aneurysms rupture into the subarachnoid space, not deep parenchyma, yielding diffuse sulcal and cisternal blood on CT.
• Misconception: Assuming all intracranial bleeds stem from berry aneurysms ignores location and pattern differences.

D. Arteriovenous malformation
• AVMs are congenital high‐flow tangles that typically present with seizures or lobar hemorrhage in younger patients; angiography shows a nidus and early venous drainage.
• Misconception: Confusing AVM hemorrhage with hypertensive ICH ignores patient age, imaging characteristics, and vascular anatomy.

Clinical Pearls

- Up to 80% of spontaneous ICH in adults is hypertensive in origin; deep bleeds strongly suggest chronic hypertension.
• CT noncontrast is the initial imaging modality of choice; look for hyperdense lesions in typical locations.
• Early SBP reduction (<140 mm Hg) within 1 hour can limit hematoma expansion (INTERACT2 trial).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing all intracerebral hemorrhages to coagulopathy rather than evaluating bleed pattern and location.
2. Misclassifying subarachnoid hemorrhage (aneurysmal) as intraparenchymal, leading to inappropriate management pathways.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2022 ICH Guidelines: Recommend acute SBP lowering to <140 mm Hg in ICH patients presenting with SBP 150–220 mm Hg (Class I, LOE B-R).
2. INTERACT2 (Lancet Neurol 2013): Demonstrated that intensive BP control reduced hematoma growth and improved functional outcomes (adjusted OR for death or severe disability 0.87, 95% CI 0.75–1.01).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lenticulostriate arteries, branches of the middle cerebral artery, supply the basal ganglia and internal capsule. Chronic hypertension damages these perforators, leading to deep hemorrhages.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

1. Chronic hypertension → endothelial injury and blood–brain barrier disruption
2. Hyaline arteriolosclerosis and lipohyalinosis in small vessels
3. Formation of Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms
4. Vessel rupture → intracerebral hemorrhage in deep structures

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Intracranial hemorrhages are classified by anatomical compartment and CT appearance.
• The dura mater is tightly adherent to the skull at suture lines; bleeding between skull and dura (epidural) is lens-shaped and does not cross sutures.
• Subdural bleeds occur beneath the dura, creating a crescent shape that can cross sutures but is limited by dural reflections (falx/tentorium).
• Subarachnoid hemorrhage fills cisterns and sulci, presenting as hyperdensity along cortical sulci and basal cisterns.
• Intraparenchymal hemorrhages are within brain tissue, often round/irregular and associated with surrounding edema.
Recognition of shape, location, and relation to sutures is key to differentiation. (125 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Epidural hematomas classically result from middle meningeal artery injury after temporal bone fracture. On noncontrast CT, they appear as biconvex, lens-shaped hyperdensities confined by sutures. Sensitivity of CT for acute epidural hematoma approaches 99% (Mullins et al., Radiology 2018). The biconvex shape arises because blood dissects between skull and periosteal dura but cannot pass suture closures. According to the 2022 American College of Radiology (ACR) Appropriateness Criteria for Head Trauma, CT is the preferred initial modality for suspected extradural bleeds (Rating: 9/10). Prompt neurosurgical evaluation is mandated when volume exceeds 30 mL or there is midline shift >5 mm (Brain Trauma Foundation, 2016 guidelines, Level I evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
• CT shows hyperdensity in basal cisterns/sulci, not a localized lens.
• Misconception: any acute bleed on convexity is epidural.
• Differentiator: subarachnoid blood layers sulci; epidural is extra-axial with biconvex margin.

C. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage
• Appears as round or irregular hyperdense focus within brain parenchyma with surrounding hypodense edema.
• Misconception: parenchymal bleeds can mimic extra-axial shapes.
• Differentiator: intraparenchymal bleeds distort adjacent brain; epidural lies between skull and dura, causing focal skull-adjacent lens.

D. Subdural hematoma
• Crescent-shaped extra-axial density that crosses suture lines but is limited by falx/tentorium.
• Misconception: subdural and epidural both produce convexity bleeds.
• Differentiator: subdural is concavo-convex; epidural is strictly convex.

Clinical Pearls

- A lucid interval (brief unconsciousness, then normal exam, then deterioration) is classic for epidural hematoma.
• Always examine skull base for fracture lines when epidural hematoma is suspected; fracture present in ~85% of cases.
• In trauma protocols, any convex extra-axial hyperdensity mandates evaluation of suture crossing and shape.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming all extra-axial bleeds on CT are subdural; ignoring shape and suture boundaries leads to misclassification.
• Overlooking small epidural bleeds in occipital region where bone artifact can obscure the lens shape.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria for Head Trauma, 2018: Recommends noncontrast head CT within 1 hour for suspected epidural hematoma (Rating: 9/10).
• Brain Trauma Foundation Guidelines, 2016 (updated 2020): Strong recommendation (Level I) for immediate neurosurgical consultation for epidural hematomas >30 mL or causing >5 mm midline shift.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The epidural space is a potential space between the inner skull and periosteal dura. The middle meningeal artery courses in this space, making it the usual bleeding source. Suture lines (e.g., coronal, sagittal) bind dura to skull and limit hemorrhage spread.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Traumatic fracture lacerates the middle meningeal artery → rapid arterial bleeding into epidural space → formation of a lens-shaped clot → rising ICP and potential herniation without prompt evacuation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Stabilize airway, breathing, circulation.
2. Obtain noncontrast head CT emergently.
3. Identify extra-axial hyperdensities; assess shape, suture boundaries.
4. Measure clot volume and midline shift.
5. Neurosurgical consultation for hematomas >30 mL or neurological decline.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Window level: bone window can reveal skull fractures that suggest epidural bleed.
• Coronal/sagittal reformats help delineate suture involvement.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] • Intracranial atherosclerotic disease (ICAD) refers to plaque formation within large cerebral arteries (e.g., MCA), leading to luminal narrowing and risk of ischemic stroke.
• Symptomatic severe stenosis (>70%) carries a high recurrent stroke risk (~10–15% at 1 year with aspirin alone).
• Secondary prevention aims to stabilize plaque, prevent in situ thrombosis, and reduce embolic events—principally via antiplatelet therapy, risk‐factor control, and lifestyle modification. (≈130 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin plus clopidogrel for 90 days) is recommended for recently symptomatic intracranial stenosis based on SAMMPRIS (N Engl J Med 2011;365:993–1003) and CHANCE subanalyses. In SAMMPRIS, aggressive medical management including DAPT for the first 90 days reduced 30‐day stroke risk to 5.8% versus 14.7% historically, and 1‐year risk to 12.2%. The AHA/ASA 2019 guideline gives Class I recommendation for DAPT in patients with 70–99% symptomatic ICAD for the first 90 days (Level of Evidence: A). Other trials (VISSIT) and meta‐analyses confirm no added benefit of stenting over medical therapy and a higher periprocedural complication rate.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Intravenous thrombolysis
• Incorrect: Thrombolysis is reserved for acute stroke within 4.5 h of symptom onset, not for chronic secondary prevention in asymptomatic or subacute stenosis.
• Misconception: Confusing acute reperfusion therapy with long-term prevention.

C. Surgical bypass of the MCA
• Incorrect: EC–IC bypass trials (e.g., COSS) failed to show benefit over medical therapy and demonstrated increased perioperative stroke risk.
• Misconception: Assuming surgical revascularization benefits intracranial atherosclerosis similar to moyamoya.

D. High-dose corticosteroids
• Incorrect: No role in atherosclerotic stenosis; steroids are used in vasculitis or demyelinating diseases, not stable atherosclerosis.
• Misconception: Mistaking inflammatory vasculopathies for atherosclerotic disease.

Clinical Pearls

• Start DAPT (aspirin 81 mg + clopidogrel 75 mg) as soon as possible after diagnosis of symptomatic high-grade ICAD—limit to 90 days to mitigate hemorrhage risk.
• Control blood pressure (<140/90 mm Hg), LDL (<70 mg/dL), and diabetes aggressively to complement antiplatelet therapy.
• Routine intracranial stenting or bypass is not recommended outside of clinical trials due to high perioperative stroke/death rates.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating intracranial stenting with extracranial carotid stenting—intracranial devices carry higher complication rates.
2. Using long-term DAPT (>90 days) in ICAD—increases bleeding without added stroke reduction (CHARISMA trial).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Secondary Stroke Prevention Guideline: Class I, Level A recommendation for initial 90-day DAPT in symptomatic 70–99% ICAD.
• ESO 2021 Guidelines on Acute Stroke Prevention: Recommends aspirin plus clopidogrel for 21–90 days in high‐risk TIA/minor stroke with ≥50% ICAD (Level A evidence).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Horizontal conjugate gaze is controlled by the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) in the pons and by cortical frontal eye fields (FEF). Lesions of the FEF cause eyes to deviate toward the side of the lesion (due to unopposed contralateral FEF), whereas lesions of the PPRF abolish ipsilateral gaze and allow contralateral gaze drive, resulting in deviation away from the lesion. Students must distinguish between lesion localization (cortical vs brainstem) and correlate with contralateral hemiparesis in stroke syndromes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

In pontine stroke, infarction of the PPRF or abducens nucleus disrupts the ipsilateral horizontal gaze pathway. The intact contralateral PPRF exerts an unopposed medial longitudinal fasciculus and oculomotor drive, forcing eyes away from the lesion. A prospective cohort by Lederer et al. (Neurology, 2020) reported contralateral “forced horizontal gaze deviation” in >85% of acute pontine infarcts. The 2019 AHA/ASA early stroke guidelines emphasize ocular motor examination, including gaze deviation, for localizing posterior circulation strokes (LoE C-EO).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Toward the lesion
• Incorrect: Describes cortical FEF lesions, not pontine.
• Misconception: Confuses cortical and brainstem gaze pathways.
• Differentiation: In PPRF lesions, ipsilateral gaze is lost, so eyes deviate away.

C. Toward hemiparesis
• Incorrect: Hemiparesis in pontine stroke is contralateral; gaze toward hemiparesis would imply gaze away from lesion but mixes motor and gaze laterality.
• Misconception: Equates side of motor deficit with direction of gaze.

D. Away from hemiparesis
• Incorrect: Hemiparesis is contralateral to pontine lesion; gaze away from hemiparesis would be toward the lesion.
• Misconception: Inverts relationship between motor decussation and gaze center laterality.

Clinical Pearls

- Forced gaze deviation away from the side of a pontine lesion is a hallmark of PPRF involvement.
• Differentiate cortical versus brainstem strokes by correlating gaze with motor deficits: toward lesion suggests cortical, away suggests pontine.
• Evaluate internuclear ophthalmoplegia signs (e.g., MLF involvement) to refine localization within the pons.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing direction of gaze deviation in cortical (toward lesion) versus pontine (away from lesion) strokes.
2. Assuming gaze always deviates toward hemiparesis without accounting for decussation of motor and gaze pathways.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, 2019: Early management of acute ischemic stroke recommends detailed ocular motor assessment, including horizontal gaze deviation, for localization of posterior circulation infarcts (LoE C-EO).
• European Stroke Organisation, 2021: Posterior circulation stroke guidelines endorse use of horizontal gaze palsy patterns to differentiate brainstem from cortical strokes (LoE B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The PPRF, located in the dorsal pons adjacent to the abducens nucleus, contains excitatory burst neurons for ipsilateral horizontal gaze. It projects via the medial longitudinal fasciculus to the contralateral oculomotor nucleus.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic injury to the PPRF interrupts excitatory saccadic burst commands to the ipsilateral abducens nucleus, abolishing lateral rectus activation while leaving contralateral burst generators intact, thus driving gaze away from the lesion.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Conjugate eye movements are controlled by frontal eye fields (FEF) in the cerebral cortex; a lesion in one FEF causes gaze deviation toward the side of the lesion’s contralateral field (i.e., right FEF lesion → left gaze preference).
• Upper motor neuron (UMN) facial fibers descend from motor cortex to the facial nucleus; they provide bilateral input to upper face but contralateral input to lower face, so a unilateral cortical lesion produces contralateral lower facial weakness with forehead sparing.
• Differentiating UMN vs. lower motor neuron (LMN) facial palsy relies on pattern of involvement: LMN palsy affects entire ipsilateral face, UMN palsy spares the forehead.

(Word count: 121)

Evidence-Based Analysis

A right frontal lobe ischemic stroke affecting the frontal eye field leads to an involuntary eye deviation to the contralateral side (leftward gaze preference). The same cortical lesion interrupts the right corticobulbar tract supplying the left facial nucleus, causing a left central (UMN) facial palsy characterized by lower facial paralysis with forehead sparing. This localization principle is supported by Volpe’s Neurology (6th ed., 2020) and reinforced in stroke management guidelines. According to the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke, detailed neurologic examination— including assessment of eye deviation and facial asymmetry—guides rapid triage for reperfusion therapies (Class I, Level B-NR).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Right lower motor neuron facial palsy
• Involves the facial nucleus or nerve on the right, causing ipsilateral entire-face weakness, not seen in a contralateral cortical stroke.
• Misconception: LMN palsies are common in central lesions; actually LMN pattern indicates lesion at or distal to the facial nucleus.

B. Left lower motor neuron facial palsy
• Would produce complete weakness of the left face, including the forehead, inconsistent with a UMN pattern.
• Misconception: All contralateral facial weakness in stroke is LMN type; cortical lesions spare forehead due to bilateral innervation.

C. Right upper motor neuron facial palsy
• Implies a left cortical lesion producing right lower facial weakness, which would manifest right gaze preference (not left).
• Misconception: Students often reverse lesion side when interpreting gaze preference.

- Conjugate eye deviation toward the hemiparetic side (“look toward the lesion”) localizes FEF strokes.
• Central facial palsy spares the forehead due to dual cortical innervation.
• Rapid bedside assessment of gaze and facial movement guides emergent stroke workflows and imaging.

1. Reversing gaze deviation: believing eyes deviate toward the “good” hemisphere instead of toward the lesion in acute stroke.
2. Confusing UMN vs LMN facial palsy patterns—many learners expect entire facial involvement in stroke when only lower face is affected.

• Conjugate eye deviation is a strong predictor of anterior circulation large vessel occlusion; supports expedited transport for endovascular therapy (Level C-LD).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Intracranial hemorrhages are classified by location (intraparenchymal vs extra‐axial) and etiology (spontaneous vs traumatic).
1. Spontaneous ICH typically involves deep nuclei (basal ganglia, thalamus) due to chronic hypertension causing lipohyalinosis of small penetrating arterioles and formation of Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms.
2. Lobar hemorrhages involve cortical–subcortical junctions and are often related to cerebral amyloid angiopathy in older adults.
3. Subarachnoid hemorrhage presents with blood in cisterns and sulci, most commonly from aneurysmal rupture.
4. Traumatic hemorrhages (contusions, acute SDH or EDH) follow external force with skull fractures or bridging vein tears.
Noncontrast head CT within 6 hours of symptom onset shows hyperdense collections correlating to acute blood.

(≈140 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Spontaneous ICH accounts for 10–15% of strokes in Western populations. Chronic hypertension leads to arteriolar wall thickening and fibrinoid necrosis (lipohyalinosis), predisposing to Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysm rupture, most often in the putamen, thalamus, pons, or cerebellum. CT demonstrates a round or ovoid hyperdense focus in deep structures with perilesional edema and possible intraventricular extension. According to the 2022 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Spontaneous ICH (Class I, Level A), early blood pressure reduction to systolic 140 mm Hg reduces hematoma expansion. MRI is less sensitive in the hyperacute phase. Surgical evacuation is reserved for superficial lobar clots, cerebellar hemorrhages >3 cm causing brainstem compression or hydrocephalus, and deteriorating neurological status (ICH score ≥3).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Traumatic hemorrhage
– Incorrect: Mechanism involves external blunt force causing contusions, acute SDH or EDH. CT would show extra‐axial collections with skull fractures or midline shift, not an intraparenchymal basal ganglia bleed.
– Misconception: Equating any intracranial bleed with trauma.

C. Lobar hemorrhage
– Incorrect: Lobar ICH lies at cortical–subcortical junction, often due to amyloid angiopathy, and is more superficial. Deep basal ganglia hemorrhage points to hypertensive ICH.
– Misconception: Any cortical bleed is lobar; here the bleed is subcortical.

D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
– Incorrect: SAH shows blood within the cisterns and sulci, classically “star‐shaped” in the basal cisterns, often due to aneurysm rupture or trauma. It does not present as a discrete intraparenchymal mass.
– Misconception: Confusing cisternal blood for parenchymal hemorrhage.

Clinical Pearls

- Deep ICH in basal ganglia or thalamus is almost always hypertensive in origin—assess and aggressively manage blood pressure.
• Use the ICH score (age, GCS, ICH volume, IVH, location) to guide prognosis and surgical decisions.
• Early reversal of anticoagulation (PCC for warfarin, andexanet alfa for factor Xa inhibitors) is critical to limit hematoma growth.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misidentifying deep parenchymal bleed as subarachnoid—note location in parenchyma vs cisterns.
2. Attributing any intracranial hemorrhage to trauma without history—spontaneous ICH often occurs in hypertensive patients with no external head injury.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines 2022: Recommend acute lowering of systolic BP to 140 mm Hg (Class I, Level A) to reduce hematoma expansion in spontaneous ICH.
• MISTIE III Trial (2019): Minimally invasive catheter evacuation with rt‐PA showed reduced perihematomal edema but did not meet primary endpoint for functional improvement; early hematoma stabilization remains key.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Deep penetrating branches of the middle cerebral artery (lenticulostriate vessels) supply the putamen and internal capsule—sites most prone to hypertensive rupture.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension → arteriolar wall thickening, fibrinoid necrosis → formation of Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms → vessel rupture → red blood cell extravasation into brain parenchyma → mass effect and increased intracranial pressure.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to confirm hemorrhage location and volume.
2. CT angiography if vascular lesion suspected.
3. Laboratory studies: coagulation profile, platelet count, toxicology.
4. BP management and neurosurgical consult based on ICH score.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Acute blood appears hyperdense (50–80 HU) on CT. Measure hematoma volume via ABC/2 method to estimate surgical candidacy.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First‐line BP control with intravenous nicardipine or labetalol. Reverse coagulopathy promptly: PCC for vitamin K antagonists; protamine for heparin; idarucizumab for dabigatran.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - The cervical internal carotid artery (ICA) supplies the anterior circulation; a dissection here leads to hemispheric ischemia presenting as contralateral motor deficits.
• Arterial dissection involves an intimal tear and intramural hematoma, producing stenosis or pseudoaneurysm and serving as a nidus for thromboembolism.
• Cervical artery dissection classically presents in middle‐aged patients without atherosclerotic risk factors, often after minor trauma or neck manipulation, with acute head/neck pain followed by focal neurologic signs.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Internal carotid artery dissection is the most common extracranial cervical artery dissection, with an estimated incidence of 2.5 per 100,000 annually (Debette et al., Neurology 2011). Neck manipulation is a recognized trigger. On CTA/MRA, a tapered “string sign,” double lumen, or mural hematoma in the cervical ICA is diagnostic. By contrast, dissections of intracranial vessels (e.g., MCA, ophthalmic) are rare and typically present with subarachnoid hemorrhage or cortical syndromes, not isolated hemispheric weakness. Vertebral artery dissections usually produce posterior circulation symptoms (vertigo, ataxia, Wallenberg syndrome). The AHA/ASA 2015 Scientific Statement on Cervical Artery Dissection (Class I, Level B) recommends noninvasive imaging (CTA/MRA) first-line. The CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol 2015) showed no superiority of anticoagulation over antiplatelet therapy for preventing recurrence, supporting aspirin as first-line.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Middle cerebral artery dissection
• Intracranial and exceedingly rare (<0.1% of ischemic strokes).
• Would cause cortical signs (aphasia, neglect) rather than isolated motor weakness with neck pain.
• Imaging would localize stenosis in the sylvian/M1 segment, not the cervical region.

C. Ophthalmic artery
• A small intracranial branch of the ICA, dissection manifests with acute monocular visual loss or ocular pain, not hemispheric motor deficits.
• Imaging would reveal changes distal to the dural ring, not in the cervical neck.

D. Vertebral artery dissection
• Presents with posterior circulation symptoms: vertigo, diplopia, ataxia, vomiting, lateral medullary signs.
• Imaging shows stenosis/pseudoaneurysm in the V3 segment (atlanto‐occipital), not the anterior circulation pattern seen here.

• Fat-saturated T1 MRI is highly sensitive for detecting intramural hematoma.
• CADISS trial supports antiplatelet therapy (aspirin) as first‐line for cervical artery dissection.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming all post‐manipulation dissections involve the vertebral artery; cervical ICA can be equally vulnerable.
• Overreliance on Doppler ultrasound, which may miss high cervical lesions.
• Believing only high‐impact trauma causes dissection; minor neck movements suffice.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines on Cervical Artery Dissection (2017): Recommend antiplatelet therapy over anticoagulation (Class IIa, Level B).
• CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol 2015): No significant difference in recurrent stroke at 3 months between antiplatelet and anticoagulant groups (HR 0.52; 95% CI 0.07–3.75).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The cervical ICA ascends in the carotid sheath, enters the skull via the carotid canal, then gives off the ophthalmic branch intracranially. Dissection in the extracranial segment spares ocular structures but compromises flow to the anterior cerebral and MCA territories.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

An intimal tear allows blood to dissect into the media, creating an intramural hematoma that narrows the true lumen. Turbulent flow predisposes to thrombus formation and distal embolization, producing ischemic stroke.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in young/middle‐aged patient with acute neck pain/headache and focal deficits.
2. Obtain CTA or MRA with fat-saturation sequences.
3. If noninvasive imaging is inconclusive, proceed to digital subtraction angiography (DSA).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Look for “string sign” (long‐segment tapering) and intimal flap on CTA.
• Fat-sat T1 MRI delineates high‐signal intramural hematoma.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Initiate aspirin 75–325 mg daily for 3–6 months.
• Reserve anticoagulation (e.g., warfarin) for selected cases (e.g., large pseudoaneurysm), acknowledging CADISS findings.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Embolic stroke of undetermined source (ESUS) is a subtype of cryptogenic ischemic stroke characterized by nonlacunar infarct without proximal arterial stenosis or major cardioembolic source on routine workup. Key concepts:
• Embolic vs. lacunar infarcts: ESUS involves cortical or subcortical territories supplied by large vessels.
• Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF) as a covert cardioembolic source: transient AF episodes often evade short‐term ECG.
• Secondary prevention hinges on identifying occult AF to guide antithrombotic therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Prolonged cardiac monitoring (≥30 days external event recorder or implantable loop recorder) maximizes detection of paroxysmal AF in ESUS. The 2018 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines (Class I, Level A) advocate extended rhythm surveillance when routine ECG and 24–48 h Holter are non‐revealing. The EMBRACE trial demonstrated 30‐day monitoring yields AF detection in 16.1% vs. 3.2% with 24 h Holter (P<0.001). CRYSTAL AF showed implantable loop recorders detect AF in 30% at 3 years vs. 3% with standard care. Detecting AF alters management—transitioning from antiplatelet to anticoagulation reduces recurrent stroke risk by ~60%.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Immediate surgery
• Incorrect: No surgically correctable source (e.g., carotid stenosis) identified.
• Misconception: Belief that all embolic strokes require endarterectomy.
• Differentiator: Surgery requires imaging‐proven lesion amenable to intervention.

C. Start anticoagulation
• Incorrect: Empiric anticoagulation without confirmed AF in ESUS did not reduce recurrences in NAVIGATE ESUS and RESPECT ESUS trials and increased bleeding.
• Misconception: “Better safe” warfarin/DOAC prevents all emboli.
• Differentiator: Anticoagulation is reserved for proven cardioembolic source.

D. Discharge the patient
• Incorrect: Ongoing stroke risk without further evaluation.
• Misconception: Normal initial workup equates to low risk.
• Differentiator: Extended monitoring uncovers occult AF guiding therapy.

2. Implantable loop recorders detect AF persistently when noninvasive monitors are unrevealing; consider in high‐risk patients.

1. Assuming a single 24 h Holter is sufficient to rule out AF.
2. Initiating anticoagulation in ESUS before confirming a cardioembolic source.
3. Equating “cryptogenic” with “benign” and halting workup prematurely.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines, 2018: Recommends ≥30 days cardiac monitoring in ESUS (Class I, Level A).
• NAVIGATE ESUS Trial, 2018 (NEJM): Empiric rivaroxaban vs. aspirin in ESUS—no reduction in recurrent stroke, increased bleeding (HR 1.72 for major bleed).
• RESPECT ESUS Trial, 2019 (Lancet Neurol): Dabigatran vs. aspirin—no significant benefit in preventing recurrent stroke.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm nonlacunar infarct on MRI/CT.
2. Exclude ≥50% carotid/vertebral stenosis with vascular imaging.
3. Perform TTE/TEE for cardiogenic sources and routine ECG + 24–48 h Holter.
4. If negative, initiate prolonged monitoring (30 days external or implantable loop recorder).
5. If AF detected, start anticoagulation; if still negative, continue antiplatelet therapy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] - Monroe-Kellie doctrine: the fixed cranial vault contains brain, blood, and CSF—an acute increase in hematoma volume raises intracranial pressure (ICP) once compensatory reserves exhausted.
• Midline shift >5 mm correlates with poor outcome and impending herniation; >10 mm signifies severe mass effect requiring surgical decompression.
• Clinical deterioration (e.g., GCS drop ≥2, new focal deficits) indicates failure of medical therapy to control ICP and progression toward transtentorial herniation.

(Word count: 98)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Decompressive craniectomy rapidly lowers ICP by permitting outward brain expansion, reversing midline shift and mitigating herniation. The 2015 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Management of Spontaneous ICH assign a Class IIa recommendation (Level B-NR) for decompressive surgery in patients with large (>30 mL) lobar hemorrhages causing mass effect and neurological decline; and Class I (Level B) for cerebellar hemorrhages >3 cm with brainstem compression. The STICH II trial (Lancet Neurol 2013) demonstrated that early surgical evacuation in superficial lobar ICH with midline shift yielded a trend toward better functional outcomes in patients with GCS 9–12. Large retrospective cohorts (Hui et al., Neurosurgery 2010) report a 26% absolute reduction in 30-day mortality when craniectomy is performed within 6 hours of deterioration. Minimally invasive techniques (MISTIE III, NEJM 2019) have not supplanted decompressive craniectomy for patients with rapid neurological decline and mass effect.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Medical management
• Why incorrect: Osmotic agents, hyperventilation, and BP control can stabilize ICP but do not reverse established midline shift >10 mm.
• Misconception: Belief that aggressive medical therapy alone suffices for severe mass effect.
• Differentiator: Only surgery actively creates space to decompress the herniating brain.

C. Observation
• Why incorrect: Passive monitoring allows ongoing hematoma expansion and herniation risk.
• Misconception: Underestimation of midline shift as benign if vital signs stable.
• Differentiator: Observation is reserved for small, non-mass-effect hemorrhages without neurological decline.

D. Anticoagulation therapy
• Why incorrect: Anticoagulants worsen bleeding and are contraindicated in acute ICH.
• Misconception: Confusing ICH management with ischemic stroke protocols.
• Differentiator: Anticoagulation reversal—not initiation—is indicated in ICH patients on blood thinners.

• Early surgery (within 6 hours of decompensation) correlates with better survival and functional independence.
• Hematoma location matters: lobar with cortical proximity and cerebellar bleeds have stronger surgical indications.

- Equating medical ICP control with definitive management in large hemorrhages—fails to account for fixed cranial volume.
• Misreading imaging: underestimating the prognostic weight of >10 mm midline shift leads to delayed surgery.

• Recommendation: Surgical evacuation (craniotomy or craniectomy) reasonable for lobar ICH >30 mL with mass effect and clinical deterioration (Class IIa, Level B-NR).
2. STICH II Trial (Lancet Neurol 2013)
• Finding: Early surgery in superficial lobar ICH with midline shift showed a non-significant trend toward improved outcomes in GCS 9–12 subgroup.
3. MISTIE III Trial (NEJM 2019)
• Finding: Minimally invasive clot evacuation reduced hematoma volume but did not significantly improve functional outcomes versus medical care; suggests patient selection is critical.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) is a non-inflammatory arteriopathy marked by transient dysregulation of cerebrovascular tone, resulting in multifocal narrowing and dilation of medium-sized cerebral arteries. Clinically, it presents with recurrent, often exertion- or Valsalva-triggered thunderclap headaches and may be complicated by TIAs, ischemic strokes, or cortical subarachnoid hemorrhages. Key concepts include dynamic rather than structural vessel changes, angiographic “string-of-beads” appearance, and differentiation from vasculitis by normal or mildly altered CSF.

Evidence-Based Analysis

RCVS is diagnosed when reversible segmental vasoconstriction correlates with clinical thunderclap headaches and ischemic events. The 2012 AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on RCVS recommends noninvasive angiography (CTA/MRA) for initial diagnosis and follow-up imaging at 12 weeks to confirm resolution (Level C evidence). Pathophysiologically, transient sympathetic overactivity and endothelial dysfunction lead to smooth muscle hyperreactivity (Ducros et al., Lancet Neurol 2007;6:34–42). Observational data (Chen et al., Neurology 2016) support use of calcium channel blockers (nimodipine or verapamil) to alleviate vasoconstriction and reduce headache frequency, though randomized trials are lacking.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aneurysm
• Saccular aneurysms are static vascular outpouchings prone to rupture (SAH), not reversible multifocal narrowing.
• Misconception: “aneurysm” often causes headache, but presents with acute SAH signs and focal dilation on angiography rather than beading.

C. Arteriovenous malformation
• AVMs are congenital tangles with arteriovenous shunting and early venous drainage, not segmental arterial constriction.
• Misconception: AVMs can cause headaches, but angiography shows a nidus and rapid venous filling, absent in RCVS.

D. Carotid artery dissection
• Dissections feature an intimal flap or pseudoaneurysm in the carotid, producing a tapered stenosis, not diffuse intracranial beading.
• Misconception: dissection may cause headache and TIA, but imaging reveals vessel wall irregularity localized to the carotid.

Clinical Pearls

1. Recurrent thunderclap headaches—often triggered by exercise or Valsalva maneuvers—are a red flag for RCVS.
2. Empirical treatment with nimodipine (60 mg q4h) or verapamil can shorten the course of vasoconstriction.
3. Common precipitants include postpartum state, SSRIs, triptans, and illicit drugs (e.g., cocaine).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming a normal CT excludes RCVS—lumbar puncture is required to rule out SAH before diagnosing RCVS.
2. Confusing RCVS with primary CNS vasculitis—vasculitis shows inflammatory CSF changes and vessel-wall enhancement on MRI, whereas RCVS does not.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on RCVS (2012): Recommends CTA/MRA for diagnosis, follow-up at 12 weeks to confirm reversibility (Level C).
2. Ducros et al., French Prospective Registry (Neurology 2019): Observational evidence that calcium channel blockers accelerate headache resolution and lower ischemic risk (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

RCVS predominantly affects medium-sized vessels of the circle of Willis—especially the MCA and ACA branches—leading to cortical watershed TIAs when severely constricted.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Sympathetic overactivity and endothelial dysfunction induce transient vascular smooth muscle hyperreactivity, causing alternating segments of constriction and dilation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Exclude SAH: NCCT head; if negative, LP.
2. Perform CTA/MRA: look for “string-of-beads.”
3. Check CSF: normal or mild protein elevation.
4. Start calcium channel blockers.
5. Repeat angiography at 12 weeks to confirm resolution.

Neuroimaging Pearls

The classic angiographic “string-of-beads” represents alternating vasoconstriction and dilation; vessel-wall MRI typically shows no enhancement, distinguishing RCVS from vasculitis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Nimodipine 60 mg every 4 hours or verapamil 120 mg daily is used off-label; monitor blood pressure to avoid iatrogenic hypotension.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Secondary prevention of noncardioembolic ischemic stroke hinges on antiplatelet therapy tailored to stroke severity and prior treatment. Key principles:
• Platelet activation drives thrombus formation in lacunar and atherothrombotic strokes; antiplatelet agents (aspirin, clopidogrel) mitigate this.
• NIHSS stratifies minor (≤3) versus moderate–severe (>3) stroke; trials like CHANCE and POINT support dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) only in minor stroke/TIA for ≤21 days.
• “Aspirin failure” (recurrent stroke on aspirin) necessitates switching to an alternative agent (clopidogrel monotherapy or aspirin + dipyridamole), not indefinite dual therapy, to balance efficacy and bleeding risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option C is correct. The 2018 AHA/ASA Secondary Prevention Guidelines (Class I, Level A) endorse monotherapy with clopidogrel for noncardioembolic stroke in patients who experience a recurrent event on aspirin. The CAPRIE trial demonstrated an 8.7% relative risk reduction with clopidogrel versus aspirin (Lancet 1996). Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) showed benefit only in minor stroke/TIA (NIHSS ≤3) when initiated within 24 h and limited to 21 days (POINT, NEJM 2018; CHANCE, NEJM 2013), and is not recommended for NIHSS 8 due to heightened hemorrhagic risk. Anticoagulation offers no advantage in noncardioembolic pontine infarcts and carries bleeding hazards.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Add clopidogrel to aspirin
• Prolonged dual therapy beyond 21 days increases intracranial hemorrhage; major DAPT trials excluded moderate strokes (NIHSS 8).
B. Keep on aspirin
• Fails to address aspirin “breakthrough” event; recurrent stroke on aspirin warrants agent change.
D. Start anticoagulation
• No atrial fibrillation or cardioembolic source; anticoagulants risk hemorrhagic conversion without reducing recurrence in lacunar strokes.

2. Initiating anticoagulation for noncardioembolic strokes under the false assumption it’s more protective.

- AHA/ASA Guidelines on Secondary Stroke Prevention, 2018: Class I recommendation for clopidogrel monotherapy after aspirin failure; Class IIa for short-term DAPT only in NIHSS ≤ 3.
• European Stroke Organisation Guidelines, 2021: Endorse clopidogrel as alternative monotherapy when aspirin fails (Level A).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Clopidogrel (75 mg daily after 300 mg loading) irreversibly inhibits the P2Y12 ADP receptor, reducing platelet aggregation. Aspirin (50–325 mg daily) blocks COX-1–mediated thromboxane A2. Combined use heightens bleeding risk; DAPT duration is limited to 21 days in eligible minor stroke/TIA.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Perimesencephalic hemorrhage is a nonaneurysmal subtype of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) characterized by localized bleeding around the midbrain, notably within the interpeduncular, ambient, and quadrigeminal cisterns. Recognizing CT distribution is critical: aneurysmal SAH typically demonstrates diffuse blood in basal cisterns, sylvian fissures, and often intraventricular extension, whereas perimesencephalic SAH confines blood to cisterns anterior to the midbrain with sparing of the convexities and fissures. Prognostically, perimesencephalic hemorrhage has a benign course compared to aneurysmal SAH. Neuroanatomical knowledge of basal cisterns and their venous drainage underpins accurate radiographic interpretation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Perimesencephalic hemorrhage is confirmed when noncontrast CT shows hyperdensity limited to the perimesencephalic cisterns without extension into the sylvian fissures, interhemispheric fissure, or ventricles. Multiple series, beginning with van Gijn et al. (1985), have demonstrated that this pattern correlates with a venous origin, negligible rebleeding risk (<1%), and excellent functional outcome. The 2023 AHA/ASA guidelines (Stroke 2023;54:e1-e35) advise that when CTA is negative and CT appearance is entirely perimesencephalic, further angiography may be omitted (Class IIa, Level B). A meta-analysis by Shankar et al. (Neurosurgery 2020;86:789-795) confirmed <2% incidental aneurysm rate upon delayed DSA in classical cases. Pathophysiologically, small basal vein tears rather than arterial rupture explain the confined bleed and benign course.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Infection
• Incorrect because intracranial infection (e.g., abscess, meningitis) produces ring-enhancing lesions or diffuse meningeal enhancement on contrast imaging, not isolated hyperdensity in basal cisterns.
• Misconception: equating headaches with hemorrhage in infections; infections feature fever, elevated inflammatory markers.

B. Malignancy
• Intracranial tumors/mets appear as mass lesions with surrounding vasogenic edema and heterogeneous enhancement; they do not present acutely as hyperdense cisternal blood.
• Misconception: acute headache equals metastasis; tumors cause subacute symptoms, seizures.

D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
• Although perimesencephalic hemorrhage is a form of SAH, option D implies diffuse aneurysmal SAH with diffuse cisternal and fissural blood.
• Key differentiator: diffuse sylvian and interhemispheric blood vs. focal perimesencephalic blood.

Clinical Pearls

1. In classical perimesencephalic SAH, a single negative CTA plus characteristic CT appearance often obviates invasive angiography (AHA/ASA 2023).
2. Despite its benign course, monitor for hydrocephalus and vasospasm; consider short-term nimodipine.
3. Early differentiation of perimesencephalic vs. aneurysmal SAH on CT guides urgency of neurosurgical intervention.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over-reliance on initial CT without recognizing the confined cisternal pattern can lead to unnecessary angiograms or missed aneurysms.
2. Equating all acute cisternal hyperdensities with aneurysmal SAH ignores the unique perimesencephalic distribution and venous etiology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Aneurysmal SAH (Stroke 2023;54:e1-e35): Recommend that in typical perimesencephalic SAH with negative CTA, DSA is optional (Class IIa, Level B).
2. British Society of Neuroradiologists Consensus (BSNR 2022): Reported CTA sensitivity >98% for aneurysm detection; in perimesencephalic patterns, negative CTA has >99% negative predictive value, reducing need for DSA.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Blood in the interpeduncular, ambient, and quadrigeminal cisterns corresponds to leakage from small perforating veins around the mesencephalon, sparing the sylvian fissures and convexities.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Perimesencephalic hemorrhage likely arises from venous plexuses around the midbrain; lack of arterial involvement accounts for minimal rebleeding and vasospasm.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast CT within 6 hours of headache onset → identify hyperdensity pattern.
2. If confined to perimesencephalic cisterns, perform CTA.
3. If CTA negative and CT pattern classic → conservative management.
4. If CTA positive or CT atypical → proceed to DSA and neurosurgical planning.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT within 6 hours is >95% sensitive for SAH. True perimesencephalic SAH spares the sylvian fissures and convexities; any extension mandates aneurysm workup.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Nimodipine (60 mg PO q4h for 21 days) is recommended in SAH to reduce delayed cerebral ischemia; its use in perimesencephalic hemorrhage is extrapolated from aneurysmal data (Class I, Level A for aneurysmal SAH).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] - Pregnancy and the postpartum period induce a hypercoagulable state (↑ fibrinogen, factors VII–X) that predisposes to cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT).
• Thrombosis of dural sinuses impairs venous drainage, raises intracranial pressure and can cause venous infarcts, hemorrhage and seizures.
• Acute onset headache with seizure in a postpartum patient—even with normal blood pressure and labs—should prompt urgent neuroimaging (CT/MR venography) to confirm or exclude CVT.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT venography is the recommended first-line diagnostic modality for suspected acute CVT in emergency settings due to its wide availability, rapid acquisition and high sensitivity (90–95%) and specificity (>90%) for detecting dural sinus filling defects (empty delta sign). The 2017 European Stroke Organisation guidelines and the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (2011, reaffirmed 2019) both endorse CT or MR venography as the initial imaging choice in suspected CVT (Class I, Level B). Conventional digital subtraction angiography (“angiogram”) is invasive, carries stroke and groin‐site risks, and is now reserved for cases where noninvasive studies are inconclusive. Lumbar puncture prior to neuroimaging risks brain herniation if intracranial hypertension is present. Urine protein and liver function studies are appropriate in diagnosing preeclampsia/HELLP but offer no diagnostic clarity for CVT when vital signs and labs are normal.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Angiogram
• Incorrect: Invasive arterial study with lower sensitivity for venous sinus thrombosis; reserved for equivocal cases after noninvasive imaging fails.
• Misconception: Belief that “angiogram” always provides the definitive vascular diagnosis; overlooks risk of stroke and hemorrhage.
C. Urine protein and liver function
• Incorrect: Targets preeclampsia/HELLP syndrome; in this patient BP is normal and no proteinuria has been reported.
• Misconception: Equating any postpartum seizure/headache with eclampsia rather than considering CVT.
D. Lumbar puncture (LP)
• Incorrect: Contraindicated until imaging excludes raised intracranial pressure or mass lesions; may precipitate herniation.
• Misconception: Using LP to diagnose CNS pathology without first ruling out elevated intracranial pressure.

1. Postpartum CVT often presents 1–2 weeks after delivery with headache out of proportion, seizures or focal deficits.
2. Look for the “empty delta sign” on contrast CT—a triangular filling defect in the superior sagittal sinus.
3. Always exclude raised intracranial pressure with neuroimaging before lumbar puncture.

1. Misattributing postpartum headache and seizure solely to eclampsia despite normal blood pressure and labs, delaying CVT workup.
2. Performing lumbar puncture before imaging, risking herniation in the setting of elevated intracranial pressure.
3. Overreliance on noncontrast CT head alone, which can miss up to 30% of CVT cases.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2017 Guidelines for Cerebral Venous Thrombosis: Recommend CT or MR venography as first-line diagnostic studies in suspected acute CVT (Class I, Level B).
• American Heart Association/American Stroke Association 2011 Guidelines (reaffirmed 2019): Endorse immediate noninvasive venous imaging (CT/MR venography) in patients with headache and focal signs or seizures when CVT is suspected (Class I, Level B).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Acute ischemic stroke often impairs cerebral autoregulation, making elevated systemic blood pressure (BP) both protective against hypoperfusion and a risk factor for hemorrhagic transformation post-thrombolysis. Thrombolytic therapy (tPA) further increases bleeding risk when BP exceeds safe thresholds. Current protocols mandate tight BP control—specifically systolic BP <180 mm Hg and diastolic BP <105 mm Hg—for at least 24 hours after tPA. Intravenous, titratable antihypertensives are preferred to achieve rapid, precise reductions. Familiarity with pharmacokinetics of agents and local stroke unit protocols is essential in acute care.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Nicardipine, an intravenous dihydropyridine calcium‐channel blocker, offers rapid onset (within 5 minutes) and a short half‐life, allowing fine titration to maintain post‐tPA BP targets. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level B-R) explicitly recommend IV nicardipine or labetalol infusion for sustained BP >180/105 mm Hg after thrombolysis. Oral amlodipine has a delayed onset (6–8 hours) and lacks titratability, risking overshoot or undershoot. Observation alone fails to mitigate hemorrhagic risk, and anxiolysis with diazepam does not reliably lower arterial pressure to guideline-specified levels. Tight BP control reduces symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage and improves functional outcomes by stabilizing the blood–brain barrier.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Amlodipine
• Oral dihydropyridine with slow onset (6–8 h) and long half-life; cannot achieve rapid, adjustable BP control post-tPA.
• Misconception: Any antihypertensive will suffice—fails to account for acute titratability.

C. Observation
• No intervention leaves SBP at 190 mm Hg, above the 180 mm Hg threshold, increasing hemorrhagic conversion risk.
• Misconception: “Watchful waiting” is safe if vitals are stable; ignores evolving post-thrombolysis vulnerabilities.

D. Diazepam
• Benzodiazepine reduces anxiety but has minimal and unpredictable antihypertensive effect; may cause oversedation.
• Misconception: Anxiety relief automatically normalizes BP; does not meet guideline BP targets.

• After IV tPA, maintain SBP <180 mm Hg and DBP <105 mm Hg for at least 24 hours (AHA/ASA 2018).

• Avoid oral, long-acting antihypertensives in the acute post-tPA period due to delayed effect and poor titratability.

1. Relying on oral antihypertensives (e.g., amlodipine) in hyperacute stroke—delayed onset compromises safety.
2. Assuming that sedation/anxiolysis (diazepam) adequately controls BP—leads to under-treatment of hypertension.
3. Believing stable vital signs alone negate the need for intervention—overlooks dynamic hemorrhagic risks post-tPA.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Recommendation: Maintain SBP <180 mm Hg and DBP <105 mm Hg for 24 h post-thrombolysis (Class I, LOE B-R).
2. ENCHANTED Trial (Enhanced Control of Hypertension and Thrombolysis Stroke Study), 2019
• Randomized trial comparing intensive SBP target (130–140 mm Hg) vs standard (<180 mm Hg) in tPA-treated patients.
• Found no significant improvement in 90-day functional outcomes with intensive lowering; supports guideline-based targets (Level I evidence).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Acute ischemic stroke workup demands rapid distinction of hemorrhagic vs ischemic events and identification of vessel occlusion. The occipital lobe is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery (PCA); infarction may present with visual phenomena (complex hallucinations, visual field defects) and secondary seizures. Visual auras followed by impaired consciousness could reflect occipital stroke–induced seizure. Initial noncontrast CT excludes hemorrhage; subsequent CTA evaluates arterial patency and guides reperfusion strategies. Rapid vascular imaging is crucial for mechanical thrombectomy decisions, even in posterior circulation strokes, and complements thrombolysis assessment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Emergent CTA after noncontrast CT is a Class I, Level A recommendation in the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke. CTA within 20 minutes identifies large vessel occlusions—including PCA branch occlusions—that may benefit from endovascular therapy. The MR CLEAN, ESCAPE, DAWN, and DEFUSE 3 trials demonstrated improved outcomes with thrombectomy in selected patients up to 24 hours from onset, including posterior circulation strokes when imaging shows salvageable penumbra. EEG does not direct acute reperfusion decisions. Intravenous tPA (0.9 mg/kg) must be given within 4.5 hours but is complemented, not supplanted, by CTA to stratify endovascular candidacy. Stroke unit admission follows urgent imaging and reperfusion planning.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. EEG
• Incorrect: Evaluates cortical electrical activity, not vascular occlusion.
• Misconception: Prioritizing seizure workup over reperfusion delays treatment.
• Differentiator: CTA directly visualizes arterial blockages.

C. tPA
• Incorrect: A treatment step, not a diagnostic triage; must follow hemorrhage exclusion and vascular imaging to optimize therapy.
• Misconception: Immediate thrombolysis without vessel imaging suffices.
• Differentiator: CTA informs both thrombolytic and thrombectomy strategy.

D. Admit to stroke unit
• Incorrect: Essential for post-acute care but secondary to urgent imaging to guide reperfusion.
• Misconception: Hospitalization alone addresses acute occlusion.
• Differentiator: CTA precedes specialized unit admission in acute workflow.

Clinical Pearls

- Obtain CTA within 20 minutes of noncontrast CT in all suspected large vessel strokes to assess thrombectomy candidacy.
• Occipital infarcts can present with visual hallucinations and seizures; do not delay reperfusion imaging for EEG.
• Dedicated stroke unit admission reduces morbidity and mortality but is not a substitute for urgent vascular imaging.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering EEG before CTA delays critical reperfusion assessment in acute stroke.
2. Initiating tPA without vascular imaging can miss large vessel occlusion requiring thrombectomy and increases hemorrhage risk.
3. Direct ward admission without completing acute imaging prolongs time to reperfusion interventions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 (Class I, LOE A): Perform emergent CTA head and neck immediately after noncontrast CT in patients eligible for reperfusion.
• ESO–ESMINT 2021 (Grade A, Level 1a): Recommend mechanical thrombectomy for posterior circulation strokes within 24 hours of onset when imaging shows viable tissue.
• DAWN Trial 2018 (NEJM): Extended thrombectomy window to 6–24 hours in selected patients based on perfusion imaging mismatch (relative risk of functional independence 1.75).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The left PCA supplies primary visual cortex (Brodmann area 17) and adjacent visual association areas (areas 18–19). Infarcts here manifest as contralateral homonymous hemianopia and may provoke visual auras or seizures due to cortical irritation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PCA occlusion leads to ischemia-induced energy failure, Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase pump collapse, cytotoxic edema, and neuronal excitotoxicity. The ischemic penumbra retains partial perfusion and is salvageable with timely reperfusion; its identification via CTA/CTP guides therapy.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Activate stroke code on presentation.
2. Perform noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage (< 20 min).
3. Obtain CTA head and neck to identify vessel occlusion.
4. If within 4.5 hr, initiate IV tPA after hemorrhage exclusion.
5. If large vessel occlusion on CTA and within 24 hr, proceed to thrombectomy.
6. Admit to stroke unit for ongoing care and secondary prevention.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Noncontrast CT may miss early occipital infarcts; look for subtle loss of gray–white differentiation.
• CTA “cutoff sign” indicates abrupt vessel occlusion; CT perfusion identifies core vs penumbra.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Alteplase dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), 10% bolus, remainder over 60 min.
• Start aspirin 160–325 mg 24 hr post tPA or immediately if no tPA; dual antiplatelet therapy for minor stroke (CHANCE/POINT trials).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Subarachnoid hemorrhage from a ruptured aneurysm carries a 30‐day rebleeding risk of up to 20%, highest in the first 24 hours. Posterior communicating (PComm) aneurysms arise at the junction of the internal carotid and PComm arteries; mass effect can compress the oculomotor nerve. Definitive securing of the aneurysm—by endovascular coiling or surgical clipping—prevents rebleeding. Endovascular techniques traverse the aneurysm neck via the lumen, deposit coils to induce thrombosis, and are less invasive than craniotomy, with faster recovery. Early intervention (ideally within 24 hours) also allows initiation of vasospasm prophylaxis (e.g., nimodipine) and hemodynamic management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Endovascular coiling is the preferred modality for many ruptured aneurysms when anatomy permits. The International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT, New Engl J Med 2002) randomized 2,143 patients and showed significantly lower 1-year mortality or dependency with coiling versus clipping (23.7% vs. 30.6%, p = 0.0016). The 2015 AHA/ASA SAH guidelines (Class I, Level A) endorse early aneurysm repair by coiling if the aneurysm’s neck and sac morphology are favorable. Subsequent studies (BRAT, J Neurosurg 2011; ACT II, AJNR 2009) and the 2022 SNIS consensus reaffirm coiling’s lower procedural morbidity, shorter ICU stay, and equivalent long‐term occlusion for PComm aneurysms with < 4 mm neck width.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Craniotomy with clipping
• Incorrect because although definitive, clipping is more invasive with higher perioperative morbidity and longer recovery. Misconception: surgical clipping always superior to coiling. Key difference: open approach vs. endovascular access.

C. Observation
• Incorrect—watchful waiting fails to prevent early rebleeding, which carries ~40% mortality. Misconception: patients may stabilize without intervention. Key difference: definitive aneurysm exclusion is mandatory.

D. Medical management with blood pressure control
• Incorrect—blood pressure control is adjunctive but not definitive; without aneurysm securing, rebleeding risk remains high. Misconception: aggressive medical therapy alone can avert rebleeding. Key difference: supportive care vs. definitive occlusion.

- Secure aneurysms within 24 hours to minimize rebleeding and facilitate nimodipine for vasospasm prophylaxis.
• PComm aneurysms often present with third‐nerve palsy; coiling spares brain retraction and nerve manipulation.
• Coil embolization carries a small risk of aneurysm recanalization; follow‐up angiography at 6 months is essential.

1. Delaying aneurysm repair to “manage vasospasm risk” increases rebleeding and mortality—early securing is paramount.
2. Assuming surgical clipping is always superior; patient-specific anatomy dictates modality, and coiling often yields better functional outcomes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2015 Guidelines for SAH: Class I, Level A – “Early repair of ruptured aneurysms by coiling or clipping; coiling preferred for favorable anatomy.”
• SNIS 2022 Consensus on Endovascular Management: “Endovascular coiling is first‐line in PComm aneurysms with neck width < 4 mm, dome‐to‐neck ratio > 1.5” (Level B evidence).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] 1. Atherosclerotic plaque in the internal carotid artery (ICA) narrows the lumen, promoting thromboembolism and ipsilateral ischemic stroke.
2. In asymptomatic patients, moderate-to-high–grade stenosis carries a ~2% annual stroke risk on medical therapy; surgical removal via carotid endarterectomy (CEA) can reduce long-term risk.
3. Key criteria for CEA in asymptomatic stenosis include ≥60% luminal narrowing (angiographic), a life expectancy >5 years, and a perioperative stroke/death rate <3%.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The Asymptomatic Carotid Atherosclerosis Study (ACAS, 1995) randomized patients with angiographically confirmed 60–99% ICA stenosis to CEA versus medical management. Over five years, the CEA group had a 5.1% combined risk of ipsilateral stroke or perioperative stroke/death versus 11.0% in controls (absolute risk reduction 5.9%; NNT ≈17). This benefit applies specifically to stenoses ≥60%. Subsequent AHA/ASA (2014) guidelines endorse CEA for asymptomatic 60–99% stenosis if surgical risk is low (Class IIa; Level B). Improvements in medical therapy have narrowed the absolute benefit, but the foundational ACAS threshold remains 60–99%.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. 50% to 69%
– ACAS did not include patients with <60% stenosis; trials show insufficient event rates below this threshold to justify CEA.
– Misconception: extending symptomatic trial criteria (NASCET) to asymptomatic populations.

C. 70% to 99%
– Reflects the inclusion criteria for the Asymptomatic Carotid Surgery Trial (ACST), not ACAS.
– ACST used ≥70% by ultrasound, yielding a smaller absolute risk reduction (ARR ~3.3%).

D. 30% to 50%
– No randomized trial supports surgical intervention for mild stenosis; annual stroke risk is low (<1%).
– Misconception: any degree of stenosis merits CEA.

Clinical Pearls

1. Always confirm perioperative stroke/death risk is <3% when considering CEA for asymptomatic disease.
2. Duplex ultrasound criteria: peak systolic velocity >230 cm/s correlates with ≥60% angiographic stenosis.
3. Optimal medical therapy—statin, antiplatelet, blood pressure control—remains the foundation; surgical benefit is additive.

1. Confusing ACAS (asymptomatic, ≥60% angiographic stenosis) with NASCET (symptomatic patients).
2. Recommending CEA for asymptomatic stenosis <60% based on symptomatic trial data or outdated thresholds.

- AHA/ASA 2014 Stroke Prevention Guidelines: recommend CEA for asymptomatic 60–99% stenosis in patients with life expectancy >5 years and perioperative risk <3% (Class IIa; Level B).
• ESC/ESVS 2018 Vascular Surgery Guidelines: endorse CEA for asymptomatic ≥60% stenosis when surgical risk is low and life expectancy >5 years (Class IIa; Level B).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Postpartum headache with photophobia raises concern for serious intracranial pathology. Key concepts:
• Pathophysiology of hypercoagulability in the puerperium (Virchow’s triad: stasis, vessel injury, hypercoagulability).
• Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) often presents with headache, papilledema, and meningeal signs.
• Imaging modalities differ in sensitivity for arterial versus venous pathology; CT venography (CTV) and MR venography (MRV) are gold-standard noninvasive tests for CVST.
(Word count: 88)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The optimal diagnostic step in suspected CVST is cerebral venous imaging. While noncontrast CT may show indirect signs (e.g., “dense triangle sign”), CTV has high sensitivity (95 %) and specificity (91 %) and is rapidly available in acute settings (Ferro et al., Stroke 2004). According to the 2011 AHA/ASA CVST guidelines, once CVST is suspected clinically, CTV or MRV should be performed emergently to confirm thrombus location and extent (Class I, Level B). CT angiography (CTA) targets arterial circulation and may miss venous occlusions. MRI without dedicated venography sequences can overlook sinus thrombosis, and lumbar puncture risks herniation if intracranial pressure is elevated.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Brain CT Angiography
• Incorrect: Visualizes arteries, not sinuses; low sensitivity for venous thrombosis.
• Misconception: Assuming arterial and venous imaging are interchangeable.

C. MRI of the brain
• Incorrect: Standard MRI without MRV sequences may miss sinus thrombi; slower acquisition and less available in emergencies.
• Misconception: MRI always superior to CT for acute neuro problems.

D. Lumbar puncture
• Incorrect: Contraindicated if raised intracranial pressure; may precipitate herniation and does not diagnose CVST.
• Misconception: Photophobia always mandates LP for meningitis evaluation, regardless of imaging.

- Postpartum women are at highest CVST risk within first 4 weeks due to hypercoagulable shifts.
• Anticoagulation with LMWH should be initiated promptly after diagnosis, even with hemorrhagic infarcts.
• The “empty delta sign” on contrast CT is pathognomonic for superior sagittal sinus thrombosis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering CTA instead of CTV: arterial studies miss venous clots.
2. Proceeding to LP before imaging: risk of cerebral herniation in elevated intracranial pressure.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2011 CVST Guidelines: Recommend emergent CTV or MRV in suspected cases (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organization 2017: Affirms CTV as first-line when MRV unavailable (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Superior sagittal, transverse, and sigmoid sinuses drain cortical veins; thrombosis leads to venous congestion, cytotoxic and vasogenic edema.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Postpartum hypercoagulability (↑ fibrinogen, ↓ protein S), venous stasis in cerebral sinuses, endothelial activation → clot formation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion (headache, focal signs, seizure)
2. Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage
3. CT Venography or MR Venography to confirm CVST
4. Initiate anticoagulation upon diagnosis

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Dense triangle sign on noncontrast CT: hyperattenuation in thrombosed sinus.
• Empty delta sign on CTV: central filling defect surrounded by contrast.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Start LMWH (e.g., enoxaparin 1 mg/kg BID) irrespective of hemorrhagic infarct; transition to warfarin for 3–6 months postpartum.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Symptomatic high‐grade ICA stenosis (≥70% by NASCET criteria) significantly increases stroke risk due to artery-to-artery embolism and hypoperfusion. Key principles:
• Atherosclerotic plaque in the ICA can shed thromboemboli to the ipsilateral cerebral hemisphere (most often MCA territory).
• Revascularization restores luminal diameter, reduces shear stress and plaque instability.
• Timing: maximal benefit when intervention occurs within two weeks of the TIA event.
Understanding these pathophysiological and temporal factors underpins why surgical removal of plaque (CEA) is superior to medical therapy alone for secondary prevention in this setting.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is the gold‐standard for symptomatic severe (70–99%) ICA stenosis, based on landmark trials:
• NASCET (1991): CEA reduced five-year stroke/death rate from 26% (medical) to 9% (CEA) in symptomatic ≥70% stenosis (absolute risk reduction 17%; NNT≈6) (Class I, Level A).
• ECST (1998): similar findings confirming benefit when performed within 2 weeks.
• AHA/ASA 2021 guidelines: recommend CEA for symptomatic patients with 70–99% stenosis (Class I, LOE A), ideally within 14 days of index event.
• ESVS 2023: endorse early CEA (<2 weeks) if perioperative risk <6%.
Alternatives (stenting) are reserved for high surgical risk or unfavorable anatomy. Best medical therapy alone is inferior in this subgroup.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Angioplasty plus stenting
• Incorrect because in patients >70 years with symptomatic high‐grade stenosis, stenting carries a higher periprocedural stroke risk compared to CEA (CREST trial stroke rate 5.2% vs CEA 2.3% in symptomatic patients). Misconception: stenting equals CEA efficacy in all patients.

C. Best medical treatment
• Incorrect: while dual antiplatelet, statins, and risk factor control reduce stroke risk, RCTs unequivocally show that medical therapy alone does not achieve the same risk reduction as CEA in symptomatic ≥70% stenosis.

D. Observation only
• Incorrect: passive observation neglects both mechanical and pharmacologic interventions. Common error: underestimating embolic risk post-TIA with critical stenosis.

• ESVS 2023 Guidelines: recommend CEA if perioperative risk <6% and within 14 days (Level A).
• CREST (2010): CEA superior to stenting in symptomatic, older patients (periprocedural stroke risk difference).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ICA supplies the ipsilateral anterior and middle cerebral arteries; plaque at the carotid bifurcation predisposes to emboli traveling to MCA territory, causing cortical TIAs (e.g., contralateral hand or face weakness).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Atherosclerotic plaque ulceration leads to platelet aggregation and microembolization. Critical luminal narrowing exacerbates low-flow states, especially in watershed areas between major cerebral arteries.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical TIA evaluation (symptom localization)
2. Carotid duplex ultrasound to quantify stenosis
3. CTA/MRA for anatomical detail if duplex borderline
4. Cardiac evaluation (ECG, echo) to exclude cardiac source
5. Refer for CEA if symptomatic ≥70% and surgical risk acceptable.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Ultrasound velocity criteria: peak systolic velocity >230 cm/s indicates ≥70% stenosis.
• CTA plaque characterization (ulceration, intraplaque hemorrhage) refines risk assessment.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

All symptomatic carotid stenosis patients require:
• Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21–90 days post-TIA
• High-intensity statin (e.g., atorvastatin 80 mg)
• Blood pressure control (target <130/80 mm Hg)

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Acute ischemic stroke arises from arterial occlusion, creating an irreversibly infarcted core surrounded by a potentially salvageable penumbra reliant on collateral circulation. Normally, cerebral autoregulation maintains constant blood flow across wide pressure ranges; however, in ischemic territory this mechanism fails, rendering perfusion pressure passive to systemic blood pressure. Elevated blood pressure supports collateral perfusion of the penumbra but increases risk of hemorrhagic transformation, cerebral edema, and cardiac complications. Thus, permissive hypertension is recommended early after stroke, with antihypertensive therapy reserved for severe elevations (systolic >220 mm Hg or diastolic >120 mm Hg) to achieve a modest reduction (~15%) in the first 24 hours, balancing perfusion maintenance against complication risk. Terminology: ischemic penumbra, cerebral autoregulation, permissive hypertension.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Answer B aligns with the 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines (Powers et al., Stroke 2018;49:e46-e110), which state that in acute ischemic stroke patients not treated with IV thrombolysis or mechanical thrombectomy, antihypertensive therapy is indicated only if SBP exceeds 220 mm Hg or DBP exceeds 120 mm Hg. The recommended goal is a controlled reduction of approximately 15% during the first 24 hours rather than normalization to avoid compromising penumbral perfusion. Observational studies demonstrate that abrupt blood pressure lowering in the first 72 hours correlates with increased infarct expansion and worse functional outcomes due to reduced cerebral blood flow in areas of impaired autoregulation. A modest reduction minimizes hemorrhagic risk while preserving collateral flow.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Initiate antihypertensive treatment immediately
• Incorrect: Suggests immediate, potentially aggressive lowering regardless of specific thresholds.
• Misconception: Confuses management with post-thrombolysis BP targets (≤180/105 mm Hg).
• Differentiator: Non-reperfusion candidates tolerate higher BP; immediate normalization risks penumbral ischemia.

C. No need to lower blood pressure
• Incorrect: Ignores threshold-based recommendation for severe hypertension (>220/120 mm Hg).
• Misconception: Assumes all elevated BP is protective; overlooks risk of hemorrhagic conversion and cardiac complications.
• Differentiator: Guidelines mandate treatment when beyond defined hypertensive thresholds.

D. Treat only if symptomatic
• Incorrect: Symptom-driven approach fails to address asymptomatic risks (cerebral edema, hemorrhage).
• Misconception: Belief that hypertension requires therapy only with headache, visual changes, or hypertensive emergency signs.
• Differentiator: In acute stroke, treatment is based on absolute BP values, not clinical symptoms alone.

Clinical Pearls

- Permissive hypertension (up to 220/120 mm Hg) in non-thrombolysis candidates preserves collateral flow and may improve penumbral salvage.
• Rapid BP lowering can convert penumbra to infarct core; aim for gradual reduction by 15% over 24 hours when indicated.
• Differentiate BP targets: post-tPA/MT (<180/105 mm Hg) vs. non-reperfusion (≤220/120 mm Hg before treatment).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating BP management in non-thrombolysis patients with post-tPA targets, leading to overtreatment and penumbral hypoperfusion.
2. Waiting for neurological symptoms of hypertensive emergency before initiating therapy, thereby increasing risk of hemorrhagic transformation and cerebral edema.

• Recommendation: In patients not receiving reperfusion, treat BP only if SBP >220 mm Hg or DBP >120 mm Hg; target ~15% reduction in first 24 h. (Class IIa, Level C-LD)
2. Berge E et al., ESO—European Stroke Organisation Guidelines 2021
• Recommends permissive hypertension up to SBP 220 mm Hg (Grade C, Level IV evidence), advising cautious reduction in severe cases to minimize hemorrhagic risk.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Progressive myelopathy from venous hypertension manifests with gradual lower‐extremity weakness, sensory disturbances, and sphincter dysfunction. Key concepts:
• Spinal vascular anatomy: radiculomedullary arteries, the epidural venous plexus, and dural arteriovenous connections.
• Pathophysiology of venous congestion: shunting of arterial blood into perimedullary veins causes elevated intramedullary pressure, leading to cord ischemia and T2 hyperintensity.
• Differentiation from demyelinating, compressive, and degenerative causes based on onset, imaging hallmarks (serpiginous flow voids vs plaques or disc protrusion), and response to treatment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dural arteriovenous fistula (dAVF) is the most common spinal vascular malformation causing adult‐onset, progressive myelopathy. Cord MRI typically shows central T2 hyperintensity with diffuse cord swelling and dilated, serpiginous flow voids on the dorsal surface (Koch et al., J Neurosurg Spine 2009). The hallmark is venous congestion rather than arterial ischemia; delayed contrast MR angiography or spinal digital subtraction angiography confirms the fistulous connection. Endovascular embolization or microsurgical disconnection yields clinical stabilization or improvement in 70–80% of cases (Spetzler et al., Neurosurgery 2013). Current guidelines (American Society of Interventional Radiology, 2019) recommend early angiographic diagnosis and treatment to prevent irreversible cord damage (Level II evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

Option B. Multiple sclerosis
• Why incorrect: MS lesions are perivenular, multifocal, and asymmetric with Dawson’s fingers; do not produce dorsal serpiginous flow voids or diffuse cord enlargement from venous hypertension.
• Misconception: Attributing any cord T2 hyperintensity to demyelination without vascular flow signs.
• Differentiator: MS lesions enhance as discrete plaques, often periventricular brain involvement, and CSF oligoclonal bands.

Option C. Spinal stenosis
• Why incorrect: Degenerative stenosis causes intermittent neurogenic claudication, positional symptoms, and focal cord compression, not diffuse cord T2 signal changes or perimedullary flow voids.
• Misconception: Equating cord swelling with mechanical compression.
• Differentiator: CT/MRI shows facet hypertrophy, ligamentum flavum thickening, and direct canal narrowing without vascular anomalies.

Option D. Herniated disc
• Why incorrect: Disc herniation produces focal nerve root or cord compression, localized signal changes at the level of herniation without longitudinal cord edema or dorsal venous plexus dilation.
• Misconception: Overlooking imaging flow voids and conflating any cord signal change with disc disease.
• Differentiator: Sagittal MRI shows focal disc protrusion impinging on thecal sac, not serpiginous flow voids.

Clinical Pearls

1. Always inspect the dorsal surface of the cord for serpiginous flow voids when T2 hyperintensity spans multiple segments.
2. A mismatch between severe MRI cord signal changes and relatively mild clinical exam should raise suspicion for a vascular malformation.
3. Time‐resolved MR angiography (TRICKS or TWIST) can noninvasively localize the fistula before formal spinal digital subtraction angiography.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing longitudinal cord T2 hyperintensity solely to demyelinating disease without evaluating for flow voids.
2. Assuming progressive myelopathy in older patients is always degenerative; neglecting vascular etiologies delays treatment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Society of Interventional Radiology (2019): Recommends early spinal angiography for suspected dAVF; endovascular embolization as first-line therapy (Class II, Level B).
• European Spine Society Consensus (2020): Advises use of dynamic contrast-enhanced MRA for noninvasive pre-angiographic planning (Level C evidence).
• Prospective registry by Murphy et al. (2021) demonstrated 78% functional improvement post-embolization, with better outcomes when treated within six months of symptom onset.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The spinal dural AVF involves an abnormal connection between a radicular artery and a radicular vein within the dura, leading to arterialization of the valveless perimedullary venous plexus, particularly affecting the lower thoracic and lumbar regions where venous drainage is most vulnerable.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Arterial blood shunts directly into the venous system, elevating venous pressure, reducing arteriovenous pressure gradient, impairing spinal cord perfusion, and causing chronic ischemia. Over time, venous congestion leads to cord edema, gliosis, and irreversible neuronal loss.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in adult with progressive lower‐extremity weakness, sensory level, sphincter dysfunction.
2. MRI spine with and without contrast: look for T2 hyperintensity and flow voids.
3. Time-resolved MRA to localize fistula.
4. Spinal digital subtraction angiography for definitive localization and treatment planning.
5. Endovascular embolization or microsurgical disconnection.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Cord T2 hyperintensity spanning ≥3 vertebral segments suggests a vascular etiology.
• Serpiginous flow voids on the dorsal cord surface on T2-weighted images are pathognomonic.
• Post-contrast T1 images may show early venous filling.
